title: Robert Courts: I voted against Theresa May's deal but Boris' treaty gives us an 'exciting, optimistic, democratic future'
text:
When Boris took office just under three months ago, his key pledge - to negotiate a new Brexit deal, ‘bin the backstop’, and take the UK out of the EU on October 31 - was met with scorn in Brussels and much of Westminster.

The EU was adamant that the Withdrawal Agreement could not be re-opened and that a deal without the backstop was impossible.

Yet here we are: a new Brexit deal has just been signed off in Brussels, with no backstop, and an exit from the EU in two weeks’ time is now within touching distance.

This alone is an enormous achievement, especially when one considers the obstacles Boris’ opponents have put in his way at every turn.

But what of the deal itself? Is it an improvement on...
description: When Boris took office just under three months ago, his key pledge - to negotiate a new Brexit deal, ‘bin the backstop’, and take the UK out of the EU on October 31 - was met with scorn in Brussels and much of Westminster.
